results.title: Our friends, why?
results.creator_credit: R. Dudfield, J. Biss and Brighton Grammar School (Vic.). Film Makers Club
results.brief_description: The story revolves around two brothers, their friends and a broken kite. When the friends find out they have been hoaxed by the brothers, there is a rumpus, but finally all shake hands and are friends again. (Award: Best film of all categories at the 1963 Milan International Festival for Young Film Makers)

results.title: Creative Activity: Our First Puppet Play
results.creator_credit: Lex Halliday, Jean Halliday and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description: A classroom film describing the steps in the production of a puppet play by primary school children. Shows the various stages in production: planning of story and action; choosing puppets; making props and backdrop; preparing stage; allotting parts; rehearsing; finally, the finished puppet show.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lex Halliday, Jean Halliday and Australian Instructional Films

results.title: Junior social studies. No. 4. Our firemen
results.creator_credit: Joan Boundy and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This film gives a simple description of fire brigades in Australia, showing their training and operation.

results.title: Operation and care of the RCA 400 16mm sound projector
results.creator_credit: Crawley Films and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: Explains by use of close-up photography the threading, operation and care of the RCA 400 16 millimetre film and sound projector. Demonstrates the correct procedures for setting up and operating the equipment. Illustrates the packing up, cleaning and lubricating of the projector.

results.title: The Opening of Canberra, Australia's capital city
results.brief_description: Shows the arrival of the Duke and Duchess of York at Parliament House. They are welcomed by the Governor-General, Lord Stonehaven and the Prime Minister, Mr. S.M. Bruce. The guard of honour is inspected and the Royal visitors are escorted into the Senate Chamber. There are also scenes of a parade of 3,000 troops and a body of returned soldiers.

results.title: One man's war
results.creator_credit: Tom Gurr, Jack S. Allan and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Made to encourage a better understanding of the meaning of the war in Korea. The film conveys impressions of the war as experienced by an Australian infantryman. Photographed on the Australian troopship, in Japan and on the South Korean battlefields.

results.title: One man's road
results.creator_credit: Robert Kingsbury, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: The life of an Aborigine and his family in reserves, country situations and Sydney. Clive and Ida Williams recall the disadvantages typical of most Aborigines’ lives in New South Wales which prevent full participation in society, and their successful assimilation in the city.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Kingsbury, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: A Hundred-Odd Years From Now
results.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Australian Dried Fruits Association and Film House Company
results.brief_description: An advertising film with a difference: Into a strange computerised future where women “run things” by controlling huge colourful computers that go bleep booble bob bob ping etc, comes Yockoo, the boy from the bush, with his satchel of dried fruits. Slowly the women overcome their cold, futuristic ways in light of Yockoo’s size, shape and overall manliness. Eventually they unearth their deep feminine sexuality and cook Yockoo a feast of dried fruit dishes using cooking utensils from their local museum. Music by Frank Smith, Photographed by Lars Gundlach, Written and designed by Weatherhead & Stitt.

results.title: One for the road
results.creator_credit: Dennis A. Hill and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: A few hours in the life of Bill Smith show why you should not mix drinking with driving. The affect of alcohol is illustrated with a model brain: although not drunk Smith’s brain power was sufficiently impaired to cause a fatal accident.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Dennis A. Hill and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Once Upon a Cheese
results.creator_credit: John Richardson, Kestrel Film Productions and Hugh Stuckey
results.brief_description: A light-hearted look at the cheese industry in Australia today. Shows how cheese is made by a fully automated process. Points out that special factories have been set up to produce cheddar. Lists the different types of cheeses - all of which are now available in Australia. Touches upon the varieties to be used with wines and beer, in cooking and how to store cheese at home.
